title: Back in ancient Greece, there were philosophers. A famous example of a Greek philosopher would be Socrates. Why were the ancient Greek philosophers called 'classical Greek philosophers'? Why are they granted the word “classical”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thank you for your question Harry, I think it is an important one. It requires, I think, a rather long answer. Prior to the conquests that are the source (materially) of “western civilization” (i.e., of its wealth), people all over the world lived in rich Civilizations that were, really, spiritually based. By this I mean that they recognized that “wealth” had a spiritual base. For example, agriculture evolved as people learned to “plant by the stars”: when to plant, when to harvest, etc. These peoples paid homage to “the Gods”/”The Great Creator”/”The Sun”/”Yawheh[for whom no word can be spoken].” These “spiritually-based” civilizations existed throughout the world: North and South America, China, Africa, Europe. Some covered large land masses (e.g., Incas, Aztecs, China), some tribal cultures (e.g., Celts, North American Indians), Some were maritime (e.g., Troy) trading with other maritime cultures. The Hebrews were, from time to time, nomadic. Some were hunters and gatherers (e.g., M’buti, Amazonian tribes). Never forget we evolved from animals — very aware of our environment, very aware of our connection to that environment – that their “knowledge” of their place in the world was passed on to us in our genetic make-up. That deep knowledge of the great goodness of our environment is lost in fear-based societies (e.g., western civilization). BUT, the people actually living under the control of material greed, can and often do maintain a spiritual foundation (e.g., African-American slaves, and their children and grandchildren, Americans who hold on to their deep cultural roots in goodness and honorability.) The archeological remains of Mesopotamia (evidence of the power, the violence, the wealth of the conquering powers) was for a long time, our oldest evidence of the horror of un-leashed human greed. [Today, our awareness of the vast collection of gold hidden in the tombs of the Altaic Gold Mountains prove that violent conquest had been advancing prior to the overthrow of agrarian cultures in the Fertile Crescent.] With their increasing wealth (based, as it was, on the work of human beings living under the control of taxation, conscription, rape, fear etc.), the conquering power of western civilization advanced along the coast of the Mediterranean, eventually conquering Greece and then Rome. Documentation: read the Iliad and the Odyssey with the recognition that the Homeric poems were for multiple generations stories passed on from peoples who actually saw the historically terrible sack of Troy and the sickness underlying our reverence for that mad-man (cruel conqueror) Ulysses. So, the greatness of Athens, its democracy, its elegance, was founded on the Greek civilization that Socrates was raised to know/honor — that Classical civilization guided his very being. At the same time, Socrates was living in the Athens that was increasingly dominated by the materialism that has no concept of that honorabililty. Socrates was honored by most people in Athens but posed a threat to those, “in power,” who sentenced him to death. Plato and Aristotle of course knew that Socrates had been put to death for his “teachings” (in quotes because Socrates never saw himself as a teacher but rather as a seeker of wisdom). We can’t know much of Platonic and/or Aristotelian teaching (i.e., philosophy) was influenced by fear of the “powers-that-be.” Nonetheless, Aristotelian philosophy is known for being logic (intellect)-based, as is all subsequent western philosophy. Intellectual argument that has no basis in external truth is a word-game — interesting perhaps but without the power to move humanity towards our greatest self. Because that era of Greek history is called the Classical Period. If follows the Archaic Period and is followed by the Hellenistic Period. In the same way, Thales and Pythagoras are considered to be “ancient" or “archaic” greek philosophers because they lived during the archaic period. Epictetus and Antiochus of Ascalon are Hellenistic Greek Philosophers. Although some who write during the Roman Period are also considered to be Hellenistic, for example Iamblichus and Plotinus. Some historians call the era between 30 BC and AD 330 the Roman Period of Greek History, but some call everything between 330 BC and AD 330 Hellenistic.

In order to distinguish them from medieval and modern Greek philosophers. There aren’t a whole lot of eminent modern Greek philosophers but there are some, and referring to the ancient ones as ‘classical Greek philosophers’ makes it clear that we’re talking about the ones from the classical era, not modern ones. I’m not sure what’s so goshdarned problematic about referring to the classical era as the ‘classical’ era, per se, but there’s not a lot anyone can do to roll that back, at this point.
